segments.text: We were talking about the bombings and how you felt about the bombings and you said that you felt that they should have been started sooner.
Would you care to continue on with that?
Well, I don't know when they started, you know, the bombings.
You said they should have started sooner.
Well, I thought you said that.
Did I think they should have started sooner?
Yeah, I asked if you thought they should have started sooner.
I don't know when they started, but they should have been going all the time, I think.
Well, they weren't.
They didn't start until the Vietnam War.
So after the advisors had been there, I mean, you know, first of all, it was just all these many, many advisors that were there, and then finally started sending troops over.

And it wasn't until later on that LBJ told people that he lied to the American people and said that they were not bombing him, and he'd already ordered them, and he manipulated people into getting them to believe that they were doing the bombing.
Let me see.
Okay.
So you believe that the bombing was extremely effective?
Yeah, it felt effective anyway.
Well, do you think it would have been more effective if they had not told the Vietnam about it?
Sure.
Is this one of the things that you were referring to back at the beginning when you said we could have won the war?
Oh, yeah.
I don't see, well, I don't think we warned anybody
the cities in Germany, when we bombed the cities in Germany.
I know we didn't warn the ones in Japan, and I know how effective those were.
We certainly didn't let them know that we were going to bomb Hiroshima.
Right, that's what I was saying.
Or Berlin.
Hitler did not know we were going to bomb Berlin.
No.
Any of the other places.
And because we didn't do that, they were effective.
I think we could have done the same thing.
They always knew whenever we were going to do anything in Vietnam.
They usually knew before we did.
Phil Caputo said that that was one of the things that really frustrated him, was that he felt the Viet Cong knew what was going on more than before the American minds had even made up their minds.
That's one of the things that bothered me, like the people coming to work in the truck.
Those people knew hours, you know, 20 hours, 10 hours.
But they didn't tell us.
They wouldn't tell us.
Was Wes Moreland at the base where you were?
No.
I don't know where.
I guess he was at MACV.
I don't know where he was at.
He might have been in, I don't know.
Do you have any Jimmy Famous generals that were there?
Oh, yeah.
Mo Meyer was there.
He was a four-star general.
I liked Mo Meyer a lot.
Had a lot of respect for him.
I saw him a lot, yeah.
But there was a lot of generals around.
You know, you didn't see them very much.
One time, I remember they had 40, like 40 generals and admirals at Tonsenute at one time for a meeting.
And, you know, we were the 7th Pacific Air Force, and that was 7th Pacific Air Force headquarters at that compound.
We didn't guard them anywhere.
Part of us did, but they were assigned to that unit.
And all of these people were at this, and they were all either generals or admirals or above that, whatever it is.
And we just knew that we were going to get hit during that time.
I don't know why we didn't, but we didn't.
But that was a lot of brass in one spot at one time.
Did you know there were more generals in Vietnam than there were in the entire Second World War?
No, I didn't know that.
Yes, there were only about five, six generals in the First Second World War.
I mean, there were very minimal ones, in excess of 30 in Vietnam.
A lot of the reason behind this was the careerism.
They needed a nice war on the record, so they went over there and they spent some time there.
So they could get it on even if they were only there six months.
There were three months that they'd been to Vietnam.
And then they came back so they could progress up the ladder.
Makes sense.
This is a proven fact.
Yeah.
Not just hearsay.
Yeah.
That it happened.
I don't know how much this was true in the Air Force because the Air Force was still, you know,
The Air Force has always been a get-in-and-get-out outfit.
Their officers didn't linger around.
Most of the ones that I've talked to, and I've talked to a great many that went to Hanoi Hilton,
They didn't stay there.
They were in the Philippines.
Yeah.
And they flew and landed there where you were, and then they took off and flew their missions and then flew back.
Right.
And they just were hit and run type things, except for the helicopters.
Yeah, there was, you know, we had a lot of, we had some reconnaissance aircraft there.
Did they have the F-84 there?
No.
I moved up to the Phantom F-4 jets.
Yeah, they had the F-4s, and then they had the A-1E Sky Raiders, or A-1s, whatever.
That's a Sky Raider.
Prop plane.
And that was Vietnamese aircraft.
They had an American commander that flew the lead aircraft.
But there was a lot of pilots there.
in and out of there because of the aircraft that was there.
And a lot of C-130s and whatnot that flew in and out of there.
I was telling you about the bounty.
We had a girl, a South Vietnamese girl that was killing pilots, killing anybody that was an American.
And she rode a motorbike, and she would
Ride by, and she used a .45 automatic, and she would kill anybody walking by.
She'd just shoot them and just never stop.
We had a very, very good shot.
In the village or at the Air Force?
In Saigon.
In Saigon.
Yeah, and on the outskirts.
And we had orders to kill her on site.
Did you kill her?
Did anybody kill her?
We, you know, we...
We looked for it.
We wanted to kill her very bad.
I was wanting to real bad.
And like I say, we were on duty just at night.
And of course, she operated a lot during that time.
And one night, we heard a motorbike coming.
And she had a driver, a man driver, drove the motorbike.
And she rode on the back.
And we heard this motorbike.
It was quiet, except for shots going off and stuff.
It was dark and it was quiet.
And this motorbike was coming in and weaved.
What she'd do is she'd ride by MP posts or security police posts and shoot them, just harass them.
She'd be gone before you could recover.
And so we heard this bike coming.
And sure enough, it was a guy driving and a girl on the back.
And so we loaded, you know, we put our M16s on full automatic, and we were going to just empty those clips, you know, same as she got.
But we had to wait for her to fire because we didn't know what she looked like.
And they all looked the same anyway, so.
Anyway, she got closer and closer, and she'd weave from one side of the street to the other.
And she'd come plumb over to where we were.
We were in a sandbag bunker.
And she got all the way over.
And we had, we were, I mean, we had her sights locked in on her.
And she never fired.
And she got down the road about 100 yards and an MP shot her with a shotgun and killed her.
He hadn't seen her before.
So you didn't get to kill her.
So somebody got to kill her.
Somebody got to kill her.
She got dead.
She got dead, but she killed a lot of pilots.
Where'd she collect the bounty from, the VC?
I don't know where they got it.
Jane found it.
I don't know where she got it.
Do you have any opinion on why there's still MIAs in Vietnam?
I don't know why.
Evidently there's some somewhere, either bodies or alive.
I can't imagine them being alive, but there could be.
I think if there is, then we should go get them out.
But I've thought that all along.
I've thought that.
You know, we should have went and got them a long time ago, if there was even a thought that they were in there.
I think we should have.
I don't think they really knew that they were there until the prisoners of war started returning.
Yeah.
Oh, I don't either.
But, you know, we knew they had prisoners before.
We didn't know how many or anything, probably, but we knew they were there.
And there was an attempt, you know, but
Yeah, I think if there's any suspicion, I would go.
You told me the other day that they told you that you were supposed to avoid, act so that you could avoid any international incidents.
Could you elaborate a little bit on that?
Well, being told that, you didn't know what that meant.
other than you weren't supposed to get involved in anything that would cause repercussions from the South Vietnamese.
And we had a couple of things that happened.
One particular one, we had a security policeman that was involved with a prostitute on the installation.
And like I said, that installation belonged to the Vietnamese.

we paid rent for the landing strips and we built them but we had to pay to use them yeah so but anyway this security policeman got in trouble with the prostitute there and what had happened they left he went to her house and she wanted money when they got there and
He wouldn't give it to her, so she started screaming.
The Vietnamese Quang Cong military police were passing and heard it.
So they stopped and captured this security policeman and take him and lock him up in a connex, which is a metal box about 10 foot cubed.
You've probably seen them.
Go ahead and describe it.
Okay, well, it's probably 10 foot.

uh cube you know the sides are all 10 foot probably pretty close to the size of it and it's solid metal anyway they locked him up in there we didn't know where he was somebody one of the guys had seen it so turned it in to our commander which was he was a lieutenant colonel and the base commander that was a vietnamese was a major
I don't remember his name now, but he was a major.
And so I found out he was in this Connex.
So our colonel took some guys in some machine gun jeeps.
We had lots of machine gun jeeps.
And he took several with him and went down to QC headquarters and told the QC to release this security policeman.
They told him no, that he was...
He was arrested and locked up for rape.
And so this lieutenant colonel told him.
He said, I want him out.
And I want him out right now.
So the Vietnamese base commander, the major, showed up.
And the major pulled a pistol on our commander.
What rank was he?
Our commander.
He was a lieutenant colonel.
OK.
And so he told him, he said, you've got one hour to release this security policeman.
And he said, if you don't, I'll turn every machine gun jeep I got loose on your headquarters.
And in an hour, he was out.
They released him.
But the next day, the guy wasn't there anymore.
So that's what you were talking about, the shifting back to the United States?
That's what we were told.
He has gone home.
Because they'd have probably killed him if he had stayed.
You ever heard those called the sweat blocks?
The hot blocks?
No.
But I knew a lot of guys that got locked up in them.
A lot of QCs that got locked up in them.
But
anyway, the national incidents, you know, you didn't do anything to offend or you wasn't supposed to.
Do you feel that your friends died for nothing?
No.
I feel like, no, I don't.
Again, you know, we all go back, it all goes back to the fact that no one knew how the Vietnam War was going to end.
Um,
You know, to say it makes me angry to hear someone say that guys died for nothing in Vietnam or fought for nothing, because that's a lie.
The kind of people I expect to hear that from is a person that deserted to Canada instead of having to go to the service.
That's like a cop out.
Those guys died fighting, and they
You know, they were fighting as hard as they possibly could.
They didn't want to die.
But they were fighting for a cause.
And a lot of those guys died, you know, from heroics doing things that they didn't have to do.
And no, I don't think they died for nothing.
I don't think they died for a cause.
Whatever that turns out to be, the war, whatever,
Somebody else has got to be responsible for that.
And, you know, for it being for the wrong reason, if it did something wrong, then I think somebody else is responsible for that.
I think that guy that fought out there was completely innocent.
I think he was fighting for the right reason.
Have you ever heard it said that the Vietnam War was a civil war going on between the internal and the country?
Yes.
I just mentioned that this was a civil war between the two countries, between North and South, much like the North and South in the United States, in which no foreign country intervened.
And yet we went over there and intervened there.
do you think we should have gone in there in the first place, irregardless of how you feel about defending your country or going to war for the United States?
Then you're not asking me as a soldier or as a citizen, but as a politician.
So you look at it as a political standpoint.
Oh, really?
Yeah, I do, yeah.
Okay.
So my asking you that question then puts it not as a soldier's,
Me asking you as a soldier, but as though you were a politician.
Or as a soldier or a citizen, instead of being the politician.
I think I could answer that.
Do you think we should have been there in the first place?
My understanding, the way I was told and the way I understood it, we were there to stop communist aggression.
which was the North, and the South wanted democracy.
Am I not right?
That was the theory, yes.
Okay, all right.
If that was the case, then I think it wasn't wrong to be there if the South wanted us to be there.
But they really didn't.
You already stated that because you said they didn't want you in their villages.
Well, now I said that.
Because of that bomb, because of that Phantom 4 bomb.
Yeah, I don't know, I don't know that that was a feeling of the South, you know.
I don't know that that was, evidently it wasn't a feeling of the government in South Vietnam.
Well, that was the Saigon government, though.
Well, it represented the South, or the people.
So, you know, evidently they wanted us there, or we wouldn't have been there, I don't believe.
But I think we went there.
I don't think it was a lot different, I don't believe, than Korea.
You had North and South Korea.
We were doing practically the same thing.
Is that right?
No, it was a little bit different.
Yeah, somewhat.
Because the majority of the people that were in South Vietnam had come from the North and went down to the South, and that was not true in Korea.
Yeah.
Korea did have some differences in Korea.
But most of those people that went from the North to the South went there because they wanted democracy, because they wanted freedom.
They didn't have that in the North.
Ho Chi Minh did not let them have that in the election.
Do you know why?
No.
Because he knew he'd lose.
Is that right?
So he wouldn't let him have it.
He was killed.
He was killed eventually.
So that was, you know, as an individual, as a voting citizen or a soldier or whatever, again, I don't think it was for me to question or make the judgment whether or not we should be there.
But the fact that we were ordered to go, I think you have to make a decision.
Either you're going to live in this country and do what you're supposed to do and what you're asked to do, like they have been ever since this country started, or move.
So then you very definitely feel, as you stated earlier, that we should not have pulled out.
No, I didn't say that we shouldn't have pulled out.
You said you should have stayed there until we won the war, that we could have won the war.
I said that we could have won it.
We could have, I think, at any time.
Well, it seems to me that maybe I'm wrong, I'm misunderstanding.
If the politicians had stayed out of it and let the...
military fighting and stayed there and won the war, then there wouldn't have been any need to pull out.
No, I don't believe there would have been.
I believe if we would have fought that war like we fought World War II, the majority of the battles in World War II, it would have been over.
In World War II, the difference was that we were fighting for territory.
That's right.
But we were not fighting for territory in Vietnam.
But we should have been.
You mean to go up into the North and move up and just flush it all out?
I think you had to do that.
So that's where to bring back in your bombings that you were talking about.
They just came in and surprised the bombings and bombed the daylights out of these people.
Civilians, you know, one thing that I can elaborate on very definitely is that we never want to see a war in this country.
If a person has ever seen, witnessed a war-torn country, and when you do, you think about home and what it does to the country, we never want to see that happen here.
The thing about it, and one of the reasons is because when there's a war, like Germany or wherever, when there's a war, civilians pay the price.
Children pay the price.
Women pay the price.
It doesn't just get the men.
I believe, I think history proves that you can't just single out the men.
and win the war.
I think you can't, like we did, I don't think you can warn villages and have all the people get out.
And, you know, villages weren't nothing.

half of them lived underground anyway back years ago in the wars they didn't in the first world war for instance they didn't bomb for a long time they didn't bomb anything might kill civilians and it was later on and then the atrocities that Hitler and the Nazis did the whole policy was changed and they started bombing and it's carried over into it and a lot of the Americans people felt that it was carried too far
in Vietnam when I don't really think I personally lived through this and was older than you are and was aware of more of what was going on but yet I didn't know anything that was going on.
It's kind of a mixed metaphor to say that I knew what was going on because I was being lied to.
I really didn't know what was going on.
I think the media hurt the war.
I blame
the media for a lot of the problems with Vietnam.
Lieutenant Kelly, for instance, you know, in the My Lai incident.
Yeah, because in the My Lai incident, I don't think he was...
I felt at the time that he was innocent of doing it deliberately.
Yeah, well.
And from what I've learned since then, I don't see how he could have avoided it.
How anybody over there could have avoided killing civilians.
Well, I don't think he can.
I know that I think he killed a lot of people needlessly, probably.
But in the first place, in that thing,
It shouldn't have ever been exposed to the American people.
It should have been kept within the military and dealt with there.
If he was guilty of what they said he was guilty of, then he should have been held, you know, a military court-martial should have been held, which it was, but it was wide open to the public.
And it shouldn't have been.
And it shouldn't have been.
It should have been confined to military people only, and it shouldn't have been publicized at all.
But the people...
demanded it, you know, so they gave it to them, you know, and they gave them Kelly, too.
Are you familiar with, it's Kelly.
Kelly.
Are you familiar with the Pentagon Papers?
No.

Well, the Pentagon Papers were the, McNamara went over there and wrote all these documents, 30-some-odd documents on what was going on in the Vietnam War, and it was supposed to be top secret in a man named Ellsberg.
He took it out, it was top secret, he took it out and gave it to the New York Times and it went to the Supreme Court.
The Supreme Court ruled that the newspapers had a right to it and they started publishing it.
And that's when the American people started finding out what was really going on in Vietnam, which they should have known all along.
Because that's what happened during the Second World War, they knew about what was going on.

What they didn't know about was that in the Second World War, it was just similar to this, to the Vietnam War in a very minute sense, is that Roosevelt was trying, just like LBJ, to get the war started.
Roosevelt tried everything he could, saying he was keeping us out of the war, to get us into the war, and finally we got into the war with the Japanese, which he was well aware of.
According to historical.
Would you have, after you came back, you spent one year there, would you have gone back for another second tour after you came back?
Would I have gone back?
Under what kind of circumstances?
Would you have just taken another tour back to Vietnam?
I didn't.
No, but would you have if you'd had a chance?
I had a chance.
Anybody did.
I mean, you can extend.
Why didn't you go back?
I liked home too much.
But even after you came back, a lot of men did go back for a second and third tour.
Some did, yeah.
I don't know the figures on it, but I do know that some did.
Oh, yeah, they did.
Some guys did it for money.
Some guys did it for, some guys are weird and just did it.
Well, that, and some guys probably did it for patriotic reasons.
I don't know.
What was it like when you came home?
And like coming home from going on vacation.
Like flying in anywhere, getting off the plane, going away.
You know, when we came back, you know, we landed in San Francisco.
And I mean, you know, it
probably the greatest moment, greatest feeling I've ever had in my life was getting home, you know, coming home.
And, uh, when we landed in, you know, there was no parties waiting for us or no people, you know, yeah, nothing like that.
I mean, it wasn't anybody.
I mean, we were, it was early in the morning and, uh, cold, which we wasn't used to.
And, uh,
So we, you know, we got on our different flights and flew home.
And when you got to your hometown, there wasn't, you know, you're just there.
Not any big hoopla like there had been before?
No, nothing.
How were you treated as a Vietnam veteran?
I wasn't treated bad.
I wasn't treated anyway, I don't suppose.
You just felt like you were ignored.
Well, nobody said anything at all, you know, I mean.
I know of guys that went through some pretty bad things that came home, you know.
But we didn't have as much problem, I don't think, in Texas as they did up north.
Why?
There was more.
I don't know why, unless it's because it's more of a rural type state.
Now, maybe in big cities they may have had more.
I don't know.
But, you know, I live in a small town.
Yes, sir.

we didn't have any demonstrations or anything like that going on, you know, or, or, uh, anybody meeting us at the plane or anything and giving us a hard time, you know, that happened in a lot of places, but it didn't, uh, I had trouble adjusting when I came back out.
Uh, when I came, we worked at night all the time.
We were, we were not out much in the daytime and, uh,
So we were white as a, you know, as a sheet.
And so we'd lay out in the sun before we came home to try to get our skin back to a natural color, you know.
And we got to where, you know, you even got to where you could see good at night.
I got to where I could see unbelievably good, I guess, because you adjusted to the darkness.
But anyway, when we came home, couldn't sleep.
And so I'd stay up at night and sleep in the daytime.
And I did that for a long time, you know, before, after we got back.
Did you start into the law business right after that?
No.
I was doing the service.
That seems to be like a night job.
How did you manage that?
Well, of course, Social Security policemen do work at night.
Yeah.
So you just worked a night shift.
But I was, yeah.
I was, no, I had a problem.
You know, I had 30 days before I went back in.
you know, back on duty.
But, you know, it was hard to do, hard to adjust.
It was kind of like being in another world, you know, after being a year.
All of a sudden, you know, that's one of the funny things about that.
If you came back on a ship, a lot of them did in World War II, you had two months or so to get ready to come back.
